definitionsEn: Used as a greeting or to begin a phone conversation
examplesEn: She said hello to her neighbor.
usageNotes: Used both formally and informally. More formal than 'hi' but less formal than 'good morning/afternoon'.
commonMistakes: Don't confuse with 'hallo' (German spelling). In English, it's always spelled 'hello'.

definitionsEn: Of a high quality or standard
Morally right or acceptable
Enjoyable or satisfying
examplesEn: We had a good time at the party.
usageNotes: One of the most common adjectives in English. Can be used in many contexts.
commonMistakes: The comparative form is 'better', not 'gooder'. The superlative is 'best', not 'goodest'.

definitionsEn: Of poor quality or low standard
Not morally good
Unpleasant or unwelcome
usageNotes: Used to describe quality, behavior, weather, health, and many other situations.
commonMistakes: The comparative form is 'worse', not 'badder'. The superlative is 'worst', not 'baddest'.

definitionsEn: A building for human habitation
The people living in a house
examplesEn: They live in a big house.
I'm going to my friend's house.
usageNotes: 'House' refers to the physical building. 'Home' refers to where you live and feel comfortable.
commonMistakes: Don't confuse 'house' (building) with 'home' (emotional connection).

definitionsEn: To put food into the mouth and chew and swallow it
examplesEn: Do you want to eat now?
usageNotes: Past tense is 'ate', not 'eated'. Past participle is 'eaten'.
commonMistakes: Don't say 'eated' - the past tense is irregular: 'ate'.

definitionsEn: To take liquid into the body through the mouth
usageNotes: Past tense is 'drank', past participle is 'drunk' - both irregular.
commonMistakes: Past tense is 'drank', not 'drinked'. Past participle is 'drunk'.

definitionsEn: To move or travel from one place to another
examplesEn: I go to school by bus.
usageNotes: Past tense is 'went', past participle is 'gone'. One of the most irregular verbs.
commonMistakes: Never say 'goed' - past tense is 'went'.

definitionsEn: To move or travel towards the speaker or towards a specified place
usageNotes: Past tense is 'came', not 'comed'. Used very frequently in everyday English.
commonMistakes: Past tense is 'came', not 'comed'.

definitionsEn: A group consisting of parents and children living together
All the descendants of a common ancestor
usageNotes: Refers to immediate family (parents, children) or extended family.
commonMistakes: 'Family' is singular, not plural. Say 'my family is', not 'my family are' (unless British English with collective noun usage).

definitionsEn: A person whom one knows and with whom one has a bond of mutual affection
examplesEn: I have many friends at school.
usageNotes: Can be used for both casual and close relationships. 'Best friend' indicates the closest relationship.
commonMistakes: Don't add 's' to make it possessive. Say 'my friend's house', not 'my friends house'.

definitionsEn: A written or printed work consisting of pages
To reserve something in advance
usageNotes: Can be both a noun (reading material) and a verb (to reserve).
commonMistakes: When used as a verb, it means to reserve, not to read.

definitionsEn: An institution for educating children
The process of being educated
examplesEn: Children go to school every day.
usageNotes: Used without 'the' when talking about the general concept: 'I go to school' not 'I go to the school'.
commonMistakes: Don't say 'to the school' when talking about education in general. Use 'to school'.

definitionsEn: A person who teaches, especially in a school
examplesEn: She wants to be a teacher.
The teacher helped me with math.
usageNotes: Used with subject: 'math teacher', 'English teacher', etc.
commonMistakes: Don't confuse 'teach' (verb) with 'teacher' (noun).

definitionsEn: A person who is studying at a school or college
usageNotes: Can be used for any level of education from primary school to university.
commonMistakes: Don't say 'studient' - the correct spelling is 'student'.

definitionsEn: To do a job or activity
A job or activity that you do regularly
usageNotes: As a verb, can be regular (works, worked) or refer to employment. As a noun, often uncountable.
commonMistakes: When talking about employment, don't use 'at work' and 'working' interchangeably without context.

definitionsEn: A colorless, transparent, odorless liquid that forms the seas and lakes
examplesEn: I drink a lot of water.
She bought a bottle of water.
usageNotes: Uncountable noun. Never say 'waters' unless referring to specific bodies of water.
commonMistakes: Don't say 'a water' - use 'some water' or 'a bottle of water'.

definitionsEn: Any nutritious substance that people or animals eat or drink
usageNotes: Uncountable noun. Use 'some food' or 'pieces/foods' when counting.
commonMistakes: Don't say 'a food' - use 'some food' or 'a type of food'.

definitionsEn: The indefinite continued progress of existence
A point measured in hours and minutes
usageNotes: Can refer to clock time, duration, or general concept. One of the most common nouns.
commonMistakes: Don't confuse 'time' (general) with 'times' (occurrences).

definitionsEn: A period of 24 hours
The time between sunrise and sunset
examplesEn: I work five days a week.
usageNotes: Used with prepositions: in the day, on Monday, during the day.
commonMistakes: Don't confuse with 'date' (specific calendar day).

definitionsEn: The period of darkness between sunset and sunrise
usageNotes: Use 'at night' (not 'in the night') for general reference.
commonMistakes: Use 'at night', not 'in the night' for general situations.

definitionsEn: The period from sunrise to noon
examplesEn: She wakes up early every morning.
usageNotes: Use 'in the morning' with 'the' or specific mornings: 'on Monday morning'.
commonMistakes: Say 'in the morning', not 'at the morning' for general times.

definitionsEn: Used to give an affirmative response
examplesEn: Would you like coffee? Yes, please.
usageNotes: Polite and formal. Informal alternatives: yeah, yep.
commonMistakes: In very formal situations, use 'yes' instead of 'yeah'.

definitionsEn: Used to give a negative response
examplesEn: No, I don't want to go.
Is there any milk? No, there isn't.
usageNotes: Can be used alone or in sentences. 'Nope' is informal.
commonMistakes: Don't use 'no' with negative verbs - it creates a double negative.

definitionsEn: Used in polite requests or questions
examplesEn: Could you please open the door?
usageNotes: Essential for politeness. Place it at the beginning or end of requests.
commonMistakes: Don't forget to use 'please' in requests - it's essential for politeness.

definitionsEn: To express gratitude to someone
usageNotes: Often used as 'thank you' or 'thanks'. 'Thank you' is more formal.
commonMistakes: Always need an object: 'thank you', 'thank him', not just 'thank'.

definitionsEn: Of considerable size or extent
examplesEn: They live in a big house.
usageNotes: Very common and versatile. Can describe physical size, importance, or degree.
commonMistakes: The comparative is 'bigger', not 'more big'.

definitionsEn: Of a size that is less than normal or average
examplesEn: Can I have a small coffee?
usageNotes: Can describe physical size, quantity, or degree.
commonMistakes: The comparative is 'smaller' or 'smaller', not 'more small'.

definitionsEn: Feeling or showing pleasure or contentment
usageNotes: Can describe temporary feelings or general disposition.
commonMistakes: Don't say 'I am happy with' - use 'happy about' or 'happy with' depending on context.

definitionsEn: Feeling or showing sorrow; unhappy
examplesEn: I feel sad when it rains.
usageNotes: Can describe temporary emotions or deeper states.
commonMistakes: Don't confuse with 'bad' - 'sad' is specifically about emotion.

definitionsEn: Recently made, discovered, or created
usageNotes: One of the most common adjectives. Can describe objects, ideas, or experiences.
commonMistakes: The comparative is 'newer', not 'more new'.

definitionsEn: Having lived for a long time
Made or used for a long time
examplesEn: We live in an old house.
usageNotes: Can refer to age of people, objects, or how long something existed.
commonMistakes: Use 'older' for comparative, not 'more old'. Use 'elderly' as a polite term for old people.

definitionsEn: An intense feeling of deep affection
To like very much
usageNotes: Can be romantic love, family love, or strong liking for things/activities.
commonMistakes: Don't overuse 'love' - 'like' is better for casual preferences.

definitionsEn: To find agreeable or enjoyable
Similar to
usageNotes: Can be a verb (to enjoy) or preposition (similar to).
commonMistakes: When used as a verb, it needs an object. Don't say 'I like' without saying what you like.

definitionsEn: To have a desire to possess or do something
examplesEn: What do you want to eat?
usageNotes: Usually followed by infinitive: 'want to do', 'want to have'.
commonMistakes: Don't say 'want that' with a full sentence. Use 'want' + object + infinitive.

definitionsEn: To require something because it is essential
usageNotes: Stronger than 'want' - implies necessity, not just desire.
commonMistakes: Don't confuse 'need' (necessity) with 'want' (desire).

definitionsEn: To use the mind to consider something
To have an opinion
usageNotes: Past tense is 'thought'. Can express opinion or mental process.
commonMistakes: Past tense is 'thought', not 'thinked'.

definitionsEn: To be aware of through observation, inquiry, or information
usageNotes: Past tense is 'knew', past participle is 'known' - both irregular.
commonMistakes: Past tense is 'knew', not 'knowed'.

definitionsEn: To create, form, or produce something
examplesEn: Can I make a phone call?
They make cars in this factory.
usageNotes: Very versatile verb with many meanings and collocations.
commonMistakes: Past tense is 'made', not 'maked'.

definitionsEn: To perceive with the eyes
To meet or visit
usageNotes: Past tense is 'saw', past participle is 'seen'.
commonMistakes: Past tense is 'saw', not 'seed'.

definitionsEn: To direct one's gaze toward someone or something
To appear or seem
examplesEn: Can I look at your book?
usageNotes: Often followed by 'at' when directing attention.
commonMistakes: Use 'look at' for directing attention, not just 'look'.

definitionsEn: To give attention to someone or something in order to hear
usageNotes: Usually followed by 'to' when specifying what is being heard.
commonMistakes: Use 'listen to' not just 'listen' when mentioning what you hear.

definitionsEn: To say words, to use the voice, or to have a conversation
usageNotes: Past tense is 'spoke', past participle is 'spoken'.
commonMistakes: Past tense is 'spoke', not 'speaked'.

definitionsEn: To mark letters, words, or symbols on a surface
examplesEn: I write in my diary every day.
usageNotes: Past tense is 'wrote', past participle is 'written'.
commonMistakes: Past tense is 'wrote', not 'writed'.

definitionsEn: To look at and understand written words
examplesEn: I read every night before bed.
examplesTr: Her gece yatmadan önce kitap okurum.
usageNotes: Past tense and participle are both 'read' but pronounced like 'red'.
commonMistakes: Past tense spelling is 'read' but pronunciation changes to /red/.

definitionsEn: To move at a regular pace by lifting and setting down each foot
examplesEn: I walk to work every day.
She walks her dog every morning.
usageNotes: Can be regular exercise or casual movement.
commonMistakes: Don't confuse with 'work' - different spelling and meaning.

definitionsEn: To move at a speed faster than walking
To manage or operate
examplesEn: The dog ran after the ball.
usageNotes: Past tense is 'ran', past participle is 'run' (same spelling).
commonMistakes: Past tense is 'ran', not 'runned'.

definitionsEn: To be in a state of rest when eyes are closed and mind is unconscious
usageNotes: Past tense and participle are both 'slept'.
commonMistakes: Past tense is 'slept', not 'sleeped'.

definitionsEn: To engage in activity for enjoyment
To perform music
usageNotes: Can refer to games, sports, music, or general leisure activities.
commonMistakes: Don't use 'play' for studying or working - it's for leisure only.

definitionsEn: To gain knowledge or skill
examplesEn: We learn new things every day.
usageNotes: Often followed by 'to' + verb or a noun.
commonMistakes: Use 'learn' for acquiring knowledge, 'teach' for giving knowledge.

definitionsEn: To devote time and attention to gaining knowledge
examplesEn: We need to study for the exam.
usageNotes: Implies more focused effort than general 'learning'.
commonMistakes: Don't confuse with 'learn' - study is the effort, learn is the result.

definitionsEn: To look at something for a period of time
usageNotes: Used for extended observation, unlike 'look' which is brief.
commonMistakes: Use 'watch' for moving things (TV, sports), 'look' for static things.

definitionsEn: To make it easier for someone to do something
usageNotes: Can be followed by object + infinitive: 'help me do it'.
commonMistakes: Don't use 'help' + 'ing'. Use 'help someone do' or 'help with'.

definitionsEn: To employ something for a purpose
examplesEn: I use my computer for work.
usageNotes: Very common verb with many applications.
commonMistakes: Don't say 'use to' for past habits - that's 'used to'.

definitionsEn: To telephone someone
To give a name to someone
examplesEn: What do you call this in English?
usageNotes: Can mean to telephone or to name someone/something.
commonMistakes: Use 'call someone' not 'call to someone'.

definitionsEn: To obtain in exchange for payment
usageNotes: Past tense is 'bought', not 'buyed'.
commonMistakes: Past tense is 'bought', not 'buyed'.

definitionsEn: To give something to someone in exchange for money
examplesEn: They sell cars at this dealership.
usageNotes: Past tense is 'sold'.
commonMistakes: Past tense is 'sold', not 'selled'.

definitionsEn: Free from dirt or impurities
To make something clean
examplesEn: I clean my house every weekend.
usageNotes: Can be an adjective or a verb.
commonMistakes: Don't confuse 'clean' (no dirt) with 'tidy' (organized).

definitionsEn: Not clean
Covered with dirt or mud
usageNotes: Can refer to physical dirt or moral impurity.
commonMistakes: The comparative is 'dirtier', not 'more dirty'.

definitionsEn: Not closed or sealed
To move a door or window to allow access
usageNotes: Can be physical state or action.
commonMistakes: Don't say 'open the light' - say 'turn on the light'.

definitionsEn: Not open
Not allowing people to enter
examplesEn: The store is closed on Sundays.
usageNotes: Refers to state of being not open.
commonMistakes: The verb is 'close' (pronounced /kloʊz/), the adjective is 'closed' (pronounced /kloʊzd/).

definitionsEn: Having a high temperature
Spicy
examplesEn: This soup is too hot to eat.
examplesTr: Bu çorba yemek için çok sıcak.
usageNotes: Can refer to temperature or spiciness of food.
commonMistakes: Can also mean spicy for food - context makes it clear.

definitionsEn: Having a low temperature
Suffering from a cold
usageNotes: Can refer to weather, temperature, or illness.
commonMistakes: 'A cold' is the illness. 'Cold' alone is temperature.

definitionsEn: Pleasing to the senses or mind
usageNotes: Used for people, places, things, and experiences.
commonMistakes: The adverb is 'beautifully', not 'beautiful'.

definitionsEn: Unpleasant to look at
Offensive to the senses
usageNotes: Can refer to appearance or behavior/attitude.
commonMistakes: The comparative is 'uglier', not 'more ugly'.

definitionsEn: Achieved without great effort
Not difficult
usageNotes: Used for tasks, activities, or situations.
commonMistakes: The comparative is 'easier', not 'more easy'.

definitionsEn: Needing much effort or skill
Not easy to do
usageNotes: More formal than 'hard'.
commonMistakes: The comparative is 'more difficult' or 'harder'.

definitionsEn: Costing a lot of money
usageNotes: Only about price, not quality.
commonMistakes: The comparative is 'more expensive', not 'expensiver'.

definitionsEn: Not costing a lot of money
Of poor quality
usageNotes: Can mean low price OR poor quality depending on context.
commonMistakes: The comparative is 'cheaper', not 'more cheap'.

definitionsEn: Correct or true
Direction opposite to left
Moral or legal entitlement
examplesEn: You have the right to remain silent.
usageNotes: Very versatile word with many meanings.
commonMistakes: Don't confuse 'write' (verb) with 'right' (correct/direction).

definitionsEn: Not correct
Not appropriate
examplesEn: Something is wrong with my car.
usageNotes: Can be about facts, directions, or morality.
commonMistakes: Don't say 'you wrong' - use 'you are wrong' or 'you're wrong'.

definitionsEn: A sentence worded to elicit information
examplesEn: The answer to your question is yes.
usageNotes: Used in academic, casual, and formal contexts.
commonMistakes: Don't confuse 'question' (noun) with 'ask' (verb).

definitionsEn: A response to a question
To respond to a question
usageNotes: Can be both noun and verb.
commonMistakes: As a verb, say 'answer the phone' not 'pick up the phone' (though both are used).

definitionsEn: Human beings in general
Members of a nation or community
usageNotes: Plural noun. 'A people' refers to an ethnic group.
commonMistakes: Don't say 'peoples' unless referring to multiple ethnic groups.
